description: Simple client server application (written in C++ and Python) based on SSL communication. Performing a MITM attack to sniff packets.
goal: Try to sniff packets flowing between an SSL client and an SSL server.
solution:
About the Lab

Implementation of a simple client-server application (written in C++ and Python) where both entities exchange data through a Secure Socket Layer connection. In order to "sniff" packets, a third party entity ("sniffer") must perform a Man-In-The-Middle attack and enable IP forwarding. The IP forwarding helps to avoid the traffic being blocked between client and server during the attack so both continue their communication without noticing anything.

The lab is composed by a server (connected to an internal_network), a client (connected to an external_network), a sniffer (connected to the same network as the client) and a router that connects the two networks and performs forwarding mechanisms.

How to

Once the lab is started, let's get access to the server container and the client container:

  1. Open a new terminal (alias Teminal 1) and type the following command: 
    docker attach ssl-sniffing-mitm-lab_server_1
  2. Then open a new terminal (alias Terminal 2) and type: 
    docker attach ssl-sniffing-mitm-lab_client_1

Here you have an output example for the server: 

Now we are able to access the source code of the client and the server, for example:

cat c++_impl/server.cpp
cat python_impl/client.py

and run the application:

  1. Start the server on Terminal 1 : 
    ./c++_impl/server
  2. Then start the client on Terminal 2: 
    ./c++_impl/client

The output of the server:

The output of the client:

From now on, the client and the server are exchanging messages and we are able to start the sniffer:

Again, new terminal (alias Teminal 3) and execute a "bash" command specifying the interactive mode (-it):

docker exec -it ssl-sniffing-mitm-lab_sniffer_1 /bin/bash

We are ready to perform a MITM attack:

First of all we need to fool the victim (client) and announce the router's IP address to be associated to our MAC and then fool the router and announce the victim's (client's) IP address to be associated to our MAC:

arpspoof -i eth0 -t 192.168.3.3 192.168.3.2 2> /dev/null &
arpspoof -i eth0 -t 192.168.3.2 192.168.3.3 2> /dev/null &

Finally, we are able to sniff packets between the two entities:

  1. Open the URL: https://localhost:14500
  2. On the wireshark GUI select "eth0" interface and start sniffig
  3. Filter packets by "ssl"

All SSL packets will be displayed on the wireshark GUI but we will not be able to read the content of these packets, of course.
author: peppe
